awd_titl_txt: MRI: Acquisition of a Three Component Particle-Image Velocimetry System to Enable Fundamental Research in Wind Engineering and Fluid Mechanics
awd_abstract_narration:
This Major Research Instrumentation (MRI) award supports the acquisition of a three-component particle-image velocity velocimetry (PIV) system to enable previously unavailable wind flow field measurements at the Wall-of-Wind (WOW) Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) facility.  These data will enable improved understanding of the correlation of peak wind loads on buildings and turbulent flows around buildings in urban settings. Enhanced understanding of the physics of turbulent wind flows may lead to major breakthroughs in both fluid mechanics and wind engineering. This knowledge enables more resilient designs that enhance economic competitiveness and reduce property loss and loss of life during severe wind events such as hurricanes.  The instrumentation will also spur new cross disciplinary research collaborations at WOW in areas ranging from pollutant dispersion in urban areas to energy systems and aerodynamics of unmanned aerial vehicles.  The instrumentation will provide enhanced student research training with hands-on PIV measurements, new experimental modules, and exposure to a broad range of fluid dynamics research.  The data from WOW experiments will be made available to community researchers through NHERI DesignSafe.

There are fundamental knowledge gaps in characterizing turbulent wind flows at high Reynolds numbers-- particularly at complex fluid-structure interfaces.  This high spatio-temporal resolution PIV system will enable simultaneous measurements of small-scale transient and turbulent flow characteristics, as well as of large-scale mean velocity field features. This will permit whole-flow-field measurements (rather than just the impact of wind on the built environment) to study fluid-structure interaction at high Reynolds numbers that cannot be achieved in conventional wind tunnels. The PIV will also provide an important tool for the validation of numerical models for turbulent flow simulations, and the fundamentals of fluid-structure interactions-- potentially leading to breakthroughs in wind engineering, fluid dynamics and high-fidelity computational fluid dynamics simulation.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Civil, Mechanical, and Manufacturing Innovation

por.por_cntn:
The 12-fan Wall of Wind (WOW) at Florida International University (FIU) is one of the shared-use national Experimental Facilities (EFs) for National Science Foundation’s (NSF) Natural Hazards Engineering Research Infrastructure (NHERI) program that provides access and expertise to users across the nation to conduct ground-breaking research with its state-of-the-art wind engineering experimental resources. The WOW is a large open jet facility with pioneering capabilities to simulate wind effects on the built environment. The major goals of the MRI project were to vastly expand the capabilities of the NHERI WOW EF and enable to transform it to a unique basic science producing multi-user facility by acquiring the instrumentation allowing interdisciplinary research by academia and industry.

The MRI project substantially improved the WOW capabilities by acquiring a unique high spatio-temporal resolution Particle Image Velocimetry (PIV) system (by LaVision) that enabled, for the first time, simultaneous measurement of small-scale transient and turbulent, and large-scale mean velocity field characteristics. The PIV system enabled the WOW EF to become a whole-flow-field measurement facility capable of measuring small- and large-scale turbulent flow structures in real-world engineering problems. The PIV system can measure all three velocity components (Stereo PIV or Volumetric particle tracking) and has the ability to be configured as a high-speed, time-resolved PIV, and a large field-of-view (LFOV) PIV system. The MRI’s specific aim is to initiate a new chapter in multi-, cross-, and trans-disciplinary research that requires study of complex flows and their effects on structures at high Reynolds numbers (Re) unachievable in conventional wind tunnels. The long-term vision for the WOW EF with this new PIV capability is to become a national “go-to” facility that supports both wind engineering and fundamental fluid mechanics research at near full-scale Reynolds numbers.

In Fall 2021, the FIU team completed its inaugural PIV project (PI: Dr. Letchford from Rensselaer Polytechnic Institute), which implemented the 3-dimensional particle tracking velocimetry (PTV) capabilities of the system to measure flow separation around a bluff body at high Reynolds number. In Fall 2022, EF staff – with continued support from LaVision personnel – conducted research for Dr. Victor Maldonado from Texas Tech University (TTU). Dr. Maldonado’s project demonstrated the PIV system’s Digital Image Correlation (DIC) technology paired with traditional 2D planar PIV measurements, which were phase-locked on a revolving 3-bladed rotor system. Additionally, the particle tracking method was applied to investigate the flow structure around the wing of an unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV) model under different flap angles in turbulent flow conditions. In Summer 2023, research was conducted for Dr. Wei Zhang from Cleveland State University. This project involved 3D PTV measurements of the conical vortices formed on the roof of a large-scale low-rise building model subjected to cornering wind directions. The PIV system also measured the mitigation effects of a porous parapet on the flow under cornering winds.

The MRI project and instrumentation provided hands-on experience and effective training to WOW research scientists/engineers (Dr. Dejiang Chen, James Erwin, Walter Conklin, and Manuel Matus). Various testing protocols were explored to enable PIV supported research topics. Improvements were made in synchronizing the acquired pressure and PTV measurements. Moreover, the PIV-enabled projects are expected to improve the quality of research training of several external graduate students who will work under the mentorship of the external collaborators to pursue research topics in fundamental fluid dynamics. PIV-based experimental modules can be designed to foster and strengthen lasting collaborations among faculty and trainees, including minority students from different disciplines (e.g., engineering, urban planning). Due to FIU’s geographical location, a predominantly minority student population, and the life-touching threats of hurricanes in South Florida, interdisciplinary activities using the integrated research-education-training test bed supported by the WOW EF and the NSF MRI acquisition will have a strong impact on increasing student participation from minority and underrepresented groups. The students working at the WOW are getting trained through the day-to-day activities, which are enhancing their performance, skills, and attitudes.

 The expected contributions of the PIV-enabled projects will help WOW EF to cross the traditional borders of wind engineering research and create an additional niche in fundamental fluid mechanics research. The research projects are expected to benefit society by reducing impacts of natural hazards, enhancing safety, increasing economic competitiveness of the US, and promoting sustainability. The efforts will promote economic prosperity, social equity, and healthy, adaptive, and resilient communities.


Last Modified: 01/02/2024
Modified by: Arindam Chowdhury
